questions.text: Given below is the image of a patient who underwent laryngectomy. Which mode of speech is he using?
questions.solution: In the image, a laryngectomy has been performed, which means the patient's larynx (voice box) has been removed. In such cases, patients often use alternative methods to produce speech. Tracheoesophageal speech is a common method used by laryngectomy patients. It involves the surgical creation of a small opening between the trachea and the esophagus, through which air can be redirected from the lungs into the esophagus. By expelling air from the esophagus, patients can produce speech sounds and communicate.

questions.text: Name the anterior most ethmoidal cell marked in the figure
questions.solution:
The anterior most ethmoidal cell is the Agger nasi cell. It is a small air cell located in the anterior part of the ethmoidal labyrinth, close to the frontal sinus and the nasofrontal beak. It is an important landmark in functional endoscopic sinus surgery (FESS) and plays a role in creating access to the frontal recess.

A. Concha bullosa: It refers to the pneumatization or presence of an air-filled cavity within one of the nasal turbinates (conchae). Concha bullosa can be found in the middle or inferior turbinates and is a common anatomical variation.

B. Bulla ethmoidalis: Bulla ethmoidalis refers to a rounded, bubble-like prominence or a pneumatized cavity in the middle meatus region of the nasal cavity. It is formed due to the pneumatization of ethmoid air cells.

D. Onodi cells: Onodi cells are the part of posterior ethmoid air cells. They line in close proximity to the sphenoid sinus, carotid artery and optic nerve.

questions.text: A patient presented to the ENT OPD with the complaint of vertigo with no hearing loss. The doctor performed a diagnostic manoeuvre and then performed a therapeutic manoeuver. Which is the diagnostic manoeuver?
questions.solution:
The Dix-Hallpike maneuver is a diagnostic maneuver that is used to induce nystagmus, which is a jerking of the eyes. Nystagmus can be caused by a number of conditions, including BPPV (benign paroxysmal positional vertigo). The maneuver is performed by having the patient lie down quickly with their head turned to one side and extended below the horizontal plane. If the patient has BPPV, they will experience nystagmus that is directed towards the side that their head is turned.

The other options are:

  • Epleys manoeuvre- This is a therapeutic maneuver that is used to treat BPPV. It is similar to the Dix-Hallpike maneuver, but the patient is rotated through a series of positions in order to reposition the otoliths that are causing the nystagmus.
  • Hemlich manoeuvre- This is a diagnostic maneuver that is used to assess the function of the vestibular system. It involves having the patient sit upright and rotate their head quickly to one side and then the other. If the patient has a vestibular problem, they will experience nystagmus that is directed towards the side that their head is turned.
  • Muller's manoeuvre- This is a therapeutic maneuver that is used to treat Ménière's disease. It involves having the patient lie down with their head tilted down and then rotated quickly to one side and then the other. This maneuver is thought to help to drain the excess fluid that is causing the symptoms of Ménière's disease.

questions.text: Name the structure marked in the figure:
questions.solution:
Pyriform Fossa

The marked structure is pyriform fossa. The pyriform fossa is an anatomical 

structure located in the hypopharynx. It is a recess or groove on each side of the larynx, bordered by the thyroid cartilage and arytenoid cartilage. The pyriform fossae are important landmarks in evaluating and diagnosing various conditions, such as laryngopharyngeal reflux and tumors of the hypopharynx.

Other options are:

  • Post cricoid: The post cricoid area is located below the level of the vocal cords, at the level of the cricoid cartilage. It is an important anatomical region in the pharynx.
  • Vallecula: The vallecula is a small depression or groove between the base of the tongue and the epiglottis. It is an important anatomical landmark in the oropharynx.
  • Pharyngeal pouch: A pharyngeal pouch, also known as Zenker's diverticulum, is an outpouching or herniation of the mucosa through the posterior pharyngeal wall. It typically occurs in the hypopharynx, above the cricopharyngeal muscle.

questions.text: Identify the given instrument
questions.solution: Lemperts Mastoid retractor: Used in mastoidectomy to retract soft tissues after incision and elevation of flaps. It's self-retracting and hemostatic.

questions.text: Which procedure is shown in the following figure
questions.solution:
The figure shows the performance of an anterior ethmoidal block. This procedure involves injecting a local anesthetic agent into the anterior ethmoidal nerve to provide anesthesia and pain relief during specific nasal surgeries or interventions.

Other options are:

  • Frontal sinus trephinationis a procedure that is performed to drain the frontal sinus. It involves making a small hole in the frontal bone to access the sinus. This procedure is not performed on the ethmoid sinuses.
  • Checking nasolacrimal duct patency ROWis a procedure that is performed to assess the patency of the nasolacrimal duct. It involves inserting a probe into the nasolacrimal duct to see if it is blocked. This procedure is not performed on the ethmoid sinuses.
  • Inferior orbital blockis a nerve block that is performed to numb the inferior orbital nerve. This nerve supplies the lower eyelid, cheek, and upper lip. This procedure is not performed on the ethmoid sinuses.

questions.text: After parotidectomy paralysis of the lower lip occurs due to the injury to which structure
questions.solution:
The cervical branch of the facial nerve is a branch of the facial nerve that supplies the muscles of the lower lip and chin region. During parotidectomy, which involves surgical removal of the parotid gland (a salivary gland located near the ear), the cervical branch of the facial nerve can be at risk of injury, leading to paralysis of the lower lip.

  • Main trunk of facial- This is the main nerve that supplies the muscles of the face. It is not injured during parotidectomy.
  • Parotid duct- This is the duct that carries saliva from the parotid gland to the mouth. It is not injured during parotidectomy.
  • Temporal branch of facial- This is a branch of the facial nerve that supplies the muscles of the forehead and temple. It is not injured during parotidectomy.

questions.text:
Which of the following is present in complicated Otitis media?
1. Bezold Abscess
2. Battle Sign
3. Delta Sign
4. Griesinger Sign
questions.solution:
A) Bezold Abscess: It can occur following acute coalescent mastoiditis when pus breaks through the thin medial side of the tip of the mastoid and presents as a swelling in the upper part of the neck. The abscess may

(i) lie deep to sternocleidomastoid, pushing the muscle outwards,

(ii) follow the posterior belly of digastric and present as a swelling between the tip of mastoid and angle of jaw,

(iii) be present in upper part of posterior triangle,

(iv) reach the parapharyngeal space

Bezold Abscess.

B) Battle's Sign: It can be related to otitis media. Battle's sign refers to bruising or discoloration behind the ear, specifically in the mastoid region. It is associated with basilar skull fractures, which can occur as a complication of severe otitis media or mastoiditis

C) Delta Sign: "Delta Sign" is commonly used in radiology to describe a characteristic radiographic finding in certain medical conditions, particularly in the context of cerebral venous sinus thrombosis (CVST).

In the context of CVST, the "Delta Sign" refers to a triangular or delta-shaped filling defect within the dural venous sinuses, most commonly seen in the superior sagittal sinus. This sign is observed on contrast-enhanced imaging, such as computed tomography (CT) or magnetic resonance imaging (MRI), and indicates the presence of a blood clot or thrombus within the sinus.

D) Griesinger's Sign: This is due to thrombosis of the mastoid emissary vein. Oedema appears over the posterior part of the mastoid.

questions.text: The x-ray shown below is done to view the frontal sinus. What is the common name of the view:
questions.solution:
The common name of the X-ray view shown to view the frontal sinus is option a: Caldwell's View.

  1. Caldwell's View: This X-ray view is obtained by positioning the patient with the chin resting on the cassette and the head tilted backward. The X-ray beam is directed through the nose and towards the film. This view allows visualization of the frontal sinuses.
  2. Water's View: Water's View is an X-ray view obtained for maxillary sinus evaluation. It involves positioning the patient with the occiput resting on the cassette, and the X-ray beam is directed through the open mouth. It provides a superior view of the maxillary sinuses.
  3. Pierre's View and d. Towne's View: Pierre's View and Towne's View are not related to frontal sinus imaging. Pierre's View is used to visualize the zygomatic arch
  4. Towne's View is used to visualize the skull base, particularly the occipital bone.

questions.text:
Which of the following Hearing tests are objective tests of hearing:
A. tympanometry
B. Brainstem Evoked Response Audiometry Ladder
C. OtoAcoustic Emissions
D. Pure Tone Audiometry
questions.solution:
Correct answer is option C: Tympanometry, Otoacoustic Emissions, and Brainstem Evoked Response Audiometry (BERA) are objective tests of hearing.

  1. Tympanometry: Tympanometry is an objective test that measures the movement of the eardrum (tympanic membrane) in response to changes in air pressure. It helps evaluate the middle ear function and detects conditions such as fluid accumulation or eustachian tube dysfunction.Brainstem Evoked Response Audiometry (BERA): BERA, also known as Auditory
  2. Brainstem Response (ABR), is an objective test that measures the electrical activity of the auditory nerve and brainstem in response to sound stimuli. It is commonly used to assess hearing in infants and individuals who are unable to participate in conventional behavioral hearing tests.
  3. Otoacoustic Emissions (OAE): OAEs are sounds generated by the inner ear in response to external auditory stimuli. They can be measured using a sensitive microphone placed in the ear canal. OAEs are used to assess the function of the cochlea and are particularly helpful in screening for hearing loss in newborns.
  4. Pure Tone Audiometry: Pure Tone Audiometry is a subjective test that relies on the patient's response to pure tone sounds of different frequencies and intensities. The patient indicates when they hear the tones, and the results are plotted on an audiogram. It is not an objective test.

questions.text: Identify the structure marked in the following Endoscopic image of Nasal cavity
questions.solution:
Structure marked in the endoscopic image of the nasal cavity is option A: Inferior Turbinate.

  1. Inferior Turbinate: The inferior turbinate is a shelf-like structure located on the lateral wall of the nasal cavity. It helps humidify, filter, and regulate the airflow within the nasal passages.
  2. Middle Turbinate: The middle turbinate is another shelf-like structure located above the inferior turbinate. It also plays a role in airflow regulation and participates in the formation of the ethmoidal air cells.
  3. Superior Turbinate: The superior turbinate is the smallest of the three turbinate structures and is located above the middle turbinate. It assists in directing airflow and participates in the drainage of the posterior ethmoidal air cells.
  4. Septum: The septum refers to the nasal septum, which is the partition dividing the nasal cavity into two halves. It consists of bone and cartilage and separates the left and right nasal passages.

choices.text: Superior olivary nucleus→ lateral lemniscus→ inferior colliculus→ medial geniculate ganglion
Superior olivary nucleus→ inferior colliculus→ lateral lemniscus→ medial geniculate ganglion
Inferior colliculi→ Superior olivary nucleus → lateral lemniscus→ medial geniculate ganglion
Inferior colliculus → Superior olivary nucleus → medial geniculate ganglion → lateral lemniscus

questions.text: Which of the following is correct sequence of auditory pathway from cochlear nucleus to auditory cortex:
questions.solution:
The correct sequence of the auditory pathway from the cochlear nucleus to the auditory cortex is superior olivary nucleus → lateral lemniscus → inferior colliculus → medial geniculate ganglion.

The auditory pathway is responsible for transmitting sound information from the cochlea to the auditory cortex in the brain. Here is a breakdown of each structure mentioned in the answer:

  • Cochlear nucleus:The cochlear nucleus is a collection of neurons in the brainstem that receive input from the cochlea. The cochlear nucleus is responsible for the initial processing of sound signals.
  • Superior olivary nucleus:The superior olivary nucleus is a collection of neurons in the brainstem that is involved in the localization of sound.
  • Lateral lemniscus:The lateral lemniscus is a tract of nerve fibers that carries sound signals from the superior olivary nucleus to the inferior colliculi.
  • Inferior colliculi:The inferior colliculi are a pair of structures in the brainstem that are involved in the processing of sound signals.
  • Medial geniculate nucleus:The medial geniculate nucleus is a collection of neurons in the thalamus that receives input from the inferior colliculi. The medial geniculate nucleus is responsible for relaying sound signals to the auditory cortex.
  • Auditory cortex:The auditory cortex is a region of the brain that is responsible for the conscious perception of sound.

questions.text: Which of the following marked structures constitute parts of the Larynx
questions.solution: B is hyoid bone which is not a part of larynx.
